column1: Gustavo A. Madero is one of the 16 municipalities into which Mexico City is divided.

column2: it became the city of "Villa de Guadalupe Hidalgo" in 1828
column3: and finally a delegación in 1931. It was named after Gustavo A. Madero
column4: the brother and fellow revolutionary of President Francisco I. Madero.

column1: The area houses the Basílica de Guadalupe
column2: the shrine of Our Lady of Guadalupe at the foot of Tepeyac Hill
column3: where Roman Catholics believe the Virgin Mary appeared to the indigenous Mexican Juan Diego Cuauhtlatoatzin  in 1531.

column2: the Northern Central Bus Station (Terminal Central del Norte) is located here
column3: providing constant bus runs to all major cities in the northern and western part of the country.

column2: the San Felipe de Jesús Tianguis in the neighborhood of the same name
column3: is  Latin America's largest tianguis or street market
